questions.question: SURVEYS
questions.description: A survey is a method of gathering information from a sample of individuals within a particular group or population. This information is then used to draw conclusions about the entire group or population.

questions.question: Was the information collected scientifically?
questions.description: Note: It’s not if it was conducted via Twitter, the Internet or by a newspaper, or a radio or TV station asking readers, listeners or viewer to call, SMS or WhatsApp to indicate their preferences.

questions.question: Who commissioned it, and why?
questions.description: Note: Be wary if it’s commissioned by a special interest group, a political party or a private corporation, this might have led to bias in the questions or in interpreting responses.

questions.question: Who does the survey cover?
questions.description: Note: Does it claim to be a survey claiming of the views of all citizens of the  country, or only a specific group?

questions.question: What was the sampling method?
questions.description: Note: Did the researcher use a specific scientific method for picking respondents or - a sure sign of an unscientific survey – or did people volunteer to participate?

questions.question: Does the sample of people polled reflect the diversity and gender of the population?
questions.description: For example: If 30% of people live in cities and 70 in rural areas and the population is 48% males and 52% female, the people polled should reflect this.

questions.question: Did you check for a sampling error and what was it?
questions.description: For example: If the survey says that 52% of respondents were in favour of a new law with 48% against it, and the margin of error is +/- 5 percentage points, it’s impossible to say “most people favour the new law”.

questions.question: How was the data collected?
questions.description: By email, telephone or in person? (Since there isn’t a cellphone directory, phone surveys generally only represent people with landlines.)

questions.question: Are rural dwellers included?
questions.description: If not, it can’t be representative

questions.question: Where the interviews done: in person, in people’s homes, or in shopping malls or on pavements?
questions.description: If they were done in places other than homes, view the results sceptically.

questions.question: How many non-responses were there, and what steps were taken to minimise non-responses?
questions.description: If the non-response rate is large that’s a problem

questions.question: When was the survey done?
questions.description: Be aware that big events can have a dramatic impact on results.

questions.question: What questions were asked, and in what order?
questions.description: The phrasing of questions can have a dramatic impact on the results. Test your own reaction to any specific question for bias– does it seem fair and or biased?

questions.question: Would most people clearly understand the questions?
questions.description: Tip: Test the questions on yourself or a friend of colleague

questions.question: Have the researchers supplied details of the questions asked, details of the people they polled, how they were selected and how, where and when the research was done?
If the researcher has not supplied details, ask for it.
questions.description: Note:  If they won’t supply details to you, rather don’t do a story? Someone who has done proper research should be happy to supply this information.
